urls.title: Presumption of innocence and related rights ‚Äì Professional perspectives
urls.description: This report looks at the practical implementation of the presumption of innocence in criminal proceedings, and related rights, in 9 EU Member States (Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Germany, Italy, Lithuania, Poland and Portugal). Article 48 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees the presumption of innocence ‚Äì but, as FRA‚Äôs research underscores, it can be undermined in many ways. These reports constitute background material for a comparative analysis for the project ‚ÄúPresumption of

urls.title: Presume innocence for all, until proven guilty ‚Äì it is a right
urls.description: Presumption of innocence is a core right in criminal justice. Yet, prejudice, bias and practices like presenting defendants in handcuffs undermine this right in many European countries, finds the latest report of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA). FRA calls on EU countries to respect the rights of all defendants, regardless of their background. ‚ÄúAll defendants have the right to be presumed innocent until an independent court finds them guilty. But our in-built biases, and what we see or read,
